ai_page.body:
Guidance for home energy improvements

Join us on our journey to become one of London’s most sustainable boroughs.

Retrofitting your home is a great way to make it greener, more energy efficient, warmer, and cheaper to run.

In this section:

  • What is retrofitting
  • How to get started
  • Sources of heat loss in your home
  • Getting the right permissions
  • Finding the right contractor
  • Things to watch out for when retrofitting

What is retrofitting

Retrofitting is when you replace or upgrade your home with new materials, products or technology.

The aim of retrofit is to make homes:

  • cheaper to run
  • warmer in winter
  • cooler in summer
  • more energy efficient
  • greener

This could involve anything from switching to LED light bulbs, improving insulation to installing solar panels.

Depending on the type and age of your house, your retrofitting needs will vary. The most common improvements include:

  • Standard upgrades: Switching to LED light bulbs, upgrading windows, and improving door seals
  • Intermediate upgrades: Insulating walls, floors, and roofs, and improving ventilation
  • Enhanced upgrades: Adding thicker insulation, installing solar panels, or switching to low-carbon heating

You can retrofit your home step by step or do everything at once. It's best to combine enhanced upgrades with any other extensions or building works.

Trustmark guide to retrofitting your home (PDF)

How to get started

You can start small with things like fixing draughts or adding insulation, and then move on to bigger improvements like solar panels or heat pumps.

There are three key areas of retrofitting:

  • energy conservation: Use less energy by making simple changes like draught-proofing and using heating controls efficiently.
  • energy efficiency: Improve your home’s insulation, glazing, and other structural elements to keep the heat in.
  • renewable energy: Once you’ve reduced energy use and improved efficiency, consider switching to renewable energy like solar power or heat pumps.

You can retrofit your home step by step or do everything at once. It's best to combine enhanced upgrades with any other extensions or building works.

Understand your home

Before you start your journey, here are some things you could do to understand your home better:

  • Check if you have a valid energy performance certificate (EPC) for your property, which lists energy efficiency improvements
  • Request a smart meter to keep track of your energy use 
  • Use a thermal imaging camera to identify areas of heat loss. If you're an Octopus Energy customer, you can borrow a camera for free

Get tailored advice

Here are some ways to get more tailored advice, that’s right for you and your home.

  • Find ways to save energy in your home - GOV.UK
  • Retrofit your home - Trustmark
  • The Retrofit Academy

Sources of heat loss

Understanding where your home loses heat is key to knowing what to fix. The main sources of heat loss are:

  • Walls: Poor insulation can cause 35-45% of heat loss
  • Roof: Up to 20% of heat can escape through an uninsulated roof
  • Floor: Older homes with uninsulated floors can lose up to 10% of heat
  • Windows and doors: Though draughts from windows and doors are noticeable, they account for less heat loss when compared to walls and roofs

Get the right permissions

Before you start work, find out if you need planning permission, or building regulations approval, especially if you live in a listed building or conservation area.

If you're a landlord, ensure your property meets Minimum Energy Efficiency Standards (EPC Band E or above). This is part of our Housing Strategy 2023-28

Even if work to your home does not need approval you should: 

  • think about the impact of measures on the heritage value of your home
  • consider whether the measure is reversible

Finding the right contractor

Make sure your contractors are: 

  • Microgeneration Certification Scheme (MCS) accredited. If installing low carbon heating systems like heat pumps.
  • Publicly Available Specification 2035 (PAS 2035) certified. For energy efficiency measures funded by public schemes
  • TrustMark registered. This Government backed scheme ensures quality workmanship

Things to watch out for when retrofitting

Some retrofit measures that are not installed properly may increase the risk of problems like:

  • damp
  • moisture build up
  • poor ventilation

To avoid these issues, start with lower risk measures like draught-proofing, and see if they improve comfort and reduce energy costs before moving on to bigger projects like solid wall insulation.

Lower-risk measures are usually more affordable and easier to reverse if needed.

To the CEO from the Web Manager, Usability Expert

Subject: Recommendations for Enhancing User Experience and Operational Efficiency Based on Customer Feedback and Content Analysis

Dear CEO,

After a comprehensive review of the current online resources and customer feedback regarding our housing improvement services, I have identified targeted areas where we can improve usability, streamline the application process, and ultimately provide a more positive experience for our residents. My findings and recommendations are as follows:

Positive Feedback Recognition:
There is minimal explicit feedback from users, yet the current content appears to be well-structured and informative. If users find the information helpful and straightforward, I would like to commend the web team for their efforts in creating detailed and comprehensive guidance pages. Keep up the good work in maintaining clear, accessible content.

Identified Improvement Areas:
Many users, especially those like David, want a simple, step-by-step process to apply for permissions related to flat improvements. Currently, our content tends to be broad and covers topics such as retrofitting, energy efficiency, and permissions in a general sense, without providing clear, actionable guidance for application procedures. 

Specifically, the issues include:
- Content about retrofitting and energy efficiency sections are not directly addressing the permissions or application process, which could cause confusion for users seeking specific application guidance.
- The permissions subsection describes when and how to get approvals but lacks explicit, step-by-step instructions, direct links to forms, or clear next steps.
- Technical details about contractor accreditation, while useful in other contexts, may seem tangential or overly complex for users only seeking permission guidance.

Recommended Improvements:
1. Refocus Content on Application Guidance:
   - Develop a dedicated, clearly titled section such as "How to Apply for Flat Improvement Permissions".
   - Include step-by-step instructions, such as:
     * How to start your application
     * Required documents (e.g., photos, plans)
     * Estimated timelines for decision-making
     * Contact points for queries
   - Incorporate direct links to online forms and relevant guidance documents.
   - Use plain language and visual aids (infographics or flowcharts) to improve accessibility.

2. Streamline and Simplify Technical Requirements:
   - Instead of detailed contractor accreditation information within the permission guidance, provide a succinct note and link to a dedicated resources page for contractors, to avoid cluttering the permission instructions.
   - Focus content on what residents need to know to submit their application confidently.

3. Clarify Key Messages:
   - Replace vague statements like "Join us on our journey..." with focused messaging such as "Learn how to get the necessary permissions for your home improvements."
   - This direct approach aligns better with user intent and improves the likelihood of successful engagement.

Impact on Customer Experience & Operational Efficiency:
Implementing these targeted refinements will:
- Reduce user confusion, leading to fewer incorrect or incomplete applications, saving staff time in clarifications.
- Shorten application processing times as residents will be better prepared with correct and complete submissions.
- Increase customer satisfaction by providing transparent, accessible, and easy-to-follow guidance.
- Ultimately, this could decrease administrative costs associated with multiple follow-ups or rework due to misunderstandings.

In conclusion, focusing on precise, actionable content centered on application processes, and simplifying technical information for clarity, will significantly improve the customer journey. This alignment of content and user needs supports service efficiencies while enhancing residents’ trust and engagement.

Please let me know if you would like a detailed mock-up of the proposed webpage improvements or further analysis.

Best regards,

[Your Name]
Web Manager & Usability Expert
